I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) four proposed 
loans to the Kingdom of Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), the 
Republic of the Union of Myanmar, and the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam; and (ii) a proposed 
grant to the Lao PDR for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Health Security Project.1 
 
2.  The project builds on previous and ongoing interventions focusing on communicable 
disease  control  (CDC)  in  Cambodia,  the  Lao  PDR,  and  Viet  Nam.2 This  project  includes 
Myanmar and focuses on the four countries’ health system strengthening, including regional 
cooperation; surveillance and outbreak response; laboratory quality and biosafety; and hospital 
infection prevention and control (IPC).3 
   
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Economic growth in the GMS is highly vulnerable to outbreaks of emerging diseases, 
such  as  severe  acute  respiratory  syndrome,  avian  influenza,  and  Middle  East  respiratory 
syndrome.4 Traditional communicable diseases, including drug-resistant malaria, dengue, and 
antimicrobial-resistant infections, also have a significant economic impact. Multiple factors play 
a role in spreading communicable diseases across borders, including an increasingly mobile 
population,  increasing  trade,  and  intensified  interaction  between  people  and  animals. 
Particularly at risk are the poor, ethnic groups, and those living in border and remote areas or 
living along economic corridors.  
 
4.   Health  systems  weaknesses  in  Cambodia,  the  Lao  PDR,  Myanmar,  and  Viet  Nam 
(CLMV) are a threat to health security in the GMS, one of the targets of the United Nations 
sustainable development goals for the health sector.5  The project will address key binding 
constraints in the countries’ health system and promote cross-country cooperation aimed at 
improving both national and international health security. 
 
5.   Countries can take advantage of synergies from coordination. In recent years, health 
authorities  in  GMS  countries  have  made  significant  progress  in  this  arena.  Cross-border 
collaboration (which includes joint outbreak investigation, information exchange, and patient 
referrals) between neighboring provinces across international borders is gaining momentum. 
However,  these  activities  need  to  be  further  integrated  and  normalized  into  routine  CDC 
activities.

4  The cost of the 2003 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome in terms of lost gross domestic product, 
measured in nominal terms, is estimated at $18 billion for the East Asian and Southeast Asian economies. 
5  Health security is achieved through a set of activities, both proactive and reactive, to minimize vulnerability to acute 
public health events that endanger the collective health of national populations.

2 
6.   Health service networks within CLMV have expanded rapidly, but marginalized, mobile, 
and  poor  people  still  have  limited  access  to  health  services.  Mobile  populations,  ethnic 
minorities, and other vulnerable groups (MEVs) and populations living in remote border areas 
are more susceptible to infectious diseases and yet tend to use health services less than the 
general population. Cross-border migrant workers returning home with HIV/AIDS or tuberculosis 
infection have limited access to treatment. Disease control programs for HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, 
and malaria are in place but often do not reach these vulnerable groups in border areas due to 
staff and funding constraints. Consequently, in CLMV, up to one-third of tuberculosis cases are 
not identified, and one-third of diagnosed tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS cases are not properly 
treated.6 
 
7.   The ministries of health (MOHs) in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam 
have  implemented  surveillance  systems  for  notifiable  diseases  and  syndromic  reporting  to 
improve reporting of events and identification of cases from the community level.7 However, the 
disease surveillance system needs further digitalization and extension to all health centers, and 
syndromic reporting needs to be rolled out nationally. Linkages and integration between disease 
surveillance, district health management information, and zoonotic disease surveillance needs 
to be improved.8 Health authorities in CLMV have to increase their capacities for risk analysis 
data management, community preparedness, and disease outbreak response. Outbreak district 
response  teams  are  often  poorly  equipped  and  financed,  and  need  capacity  building  on 
outbreak investigation and management. 
  
8.   Past investments have improved laboratory services in provincial hospitals. In contrast, 
district  hospital  laboratories  are  unable  to  comply  with  internationally  acceptable  biosafety 
standards or to guarantee the accuracy of their laboratory tests. Underlying problems include 
substandard  training  of  laboratory  staff,  and  insufficient  equipment  and  supplies.  Formal 
processes  for  internal  and  external  quality  assurance  are  lacking.  Laboratory  auditing  for 
compliance with quality and safety guidelines does not exist. 
  
9.   Hospitals and health centers are most likely to receive patients with emerging infectious 
diseases, but IPC practices in health facilities are substandard. Hospital sanitation and hygiene 
facilities are lacking. Hospital medical waste management is often unsatisfactory. The general 
public has almost unrestricted access to infectious patients’ wards. Such practices may result in 
ineffective treatment, the spread of infectious diseases, increased hospital-acquired infections, 
and development of drug resistance. 
 
10.   The governments have demonstrated strong commitment and leadership towards the 
control of emerging infectious diseases and other diseases of regional importance. National 
policies and plans are in place to deal with these major health threats. CLMV have stepped up 
domestic financing and mobilization of external assistance to improve cross-border cooperation. 
CLMV are committed to achieve standards based on the International Health Regulations, 2005, 
in  line  with  the  strategic  framework  of  the  Asia  Pacific  Strategy  for  Emerging  Diseases 
(APSED), 2010, both of the World Health Organization (WHO). 9 The APSED, 2010 includes 
eight  focus  areas:  (i)  regional  preparedness,  alert,  and  response;  (ii)  surveillance,  risk

laboratories; (vi) IPC; (vii) zoonotic diseases; and (viii) public health emergency preparedness. 
CLMV governments have developed, or are developing, national strategies to increase quality 
of laboratories and improve hospital IPC, based on WHO guidelines. 
   
11.   The  Midterm  Review  of  Strategy  2020  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
recommends expanding operations in the health sector to 3%–5% of ADB’s annual approvals.10 
The project is in line with ADB’s Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020.11 The project is 
included in the GMS Regional Investment Framework Implementation Plan, 2014–2018; and is 
aligned with the CLMV country partnership strategies.12 The project is included in the current 
country operations business plans of CLMV.13 The project addresses regional public goods as 
described in ADB’s regional cooperation and integration strategy.14 ADB has supported several 
loans and grants focusing on CDC (footnote 2); multiple loans, grants, and technical assistance 
projects focusing  on  HIV/AIDS;  and  a  number  of grants  and  technical  assistance  projects 
focusing on malaria15 financed from ADB’s Regional Malaria and Other Communicable Disease 
Threats Trust Fund under the Health Financing Partnership Facility.16  
 
12.   Lessons  learned  from  previous  and  current  interventions  include  the  following:              
(i) district hospitals are better positioned than provincial hospitals to conduct CDC activities;    
(ii) strengthening the health system is more important than focusing on a single disease; (iii) the 
provision of laboratory equipment must be accompanied by measures improving quality and 
accuracy of diagnostics; (iv) IPC in the district hospitals is essential for effective and prompt 
control of outbreaks; and (v) the support for regional cooperation has to be aligned with existing 
regional frameworks such as the APSED

and the World Bank for hospital infection control in Viet Nam. The project will complement these 
existing interventions by (i) addressing gaps in laboratory diagnostic capacity in hospital IPC in 
remote area, (ii) strengthening the health system generally rather than concentrating on disease 
specific  interventions,  and  (iii)  fostering  regional  cooperation  for  public  goods.  Further,  as 
CLMV’s national income per capita increases, future financing by the Global Fund to Fight 
HIV/AIDS,  Tuberculosis,  and  Malaria,  and  bilateral  development  partners  is  uncertain  and 
ADB’s support seeks to fill this impending gap.  
 
B.   Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The impact will be GMS public health security strengthened. The outcome will be GMS 
health system performance with regard to health security improved. The project locations are 
selected provinces along borders and economic corridors. In these locations, health facilities 
typically serve the local population as well as mobile and migrant populations. The selection 
criteria for project provinces, states, and regions are (i) high poverty incidence; (ii) high burden 
of communicable disease; (iii) high regional risk of disease outbreaks; and (v) limited support 
from other development partners. The project will cover 13 provinces in Cambodia, 12 provinces 
in the Lao PDR, five states and regions in Myanmar, and 36 provinces in Viet Nam.17 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
15.  The project will have three outputs:  
 
(i)  Output  1:  Regional  cooperation  and  communicable  disease  control  in 
border areas improved. This output will strengthen APSED focus areas 1, 3, 
and 4 (para. 10). Under this output, the project will strengthen (i) regional, cross-
border, and intersectoral information sharing and coordination of outbreak control 
among  GMS  countries;  (ii)  regional  capacity  for  evidence-based  CDC;  (iii) 
development of better disease control strategies for MEVs in border areas; and 
(iv) improved CDC services for MEVs in hotspots along economic corridors in 
targeted border areas. The project will provide technical expertise and funding, to 
improve information exchange between CLMV countries and foster intersectoral 
collaboration. The project will finance cross-border activities (including simulation 
exercises, and joint outbreak investigation and control), and outreach activities 
targeting MEVs. The regional coordination unit, hosted by the MOH of the Lao 
PDR and financed under a regional technical assistance project, will provide 
technical support to CLMV for information exchange, disease control strategies 
for MEVs, and organization of regional events.18

(ii)  Output 2: National disease surveillance and outbreak response systems 
strengthened. This output will strengthen APSED focus areas 1, 2, 3, 7, and 8 
(para. 10). Under this output, the project will support (i) syndromic reporting at 
the community level; (ii) web-based reporting; (iii) linking of disease surveillance 
systems, including between clinical and laboratory surveillance; (iv) improving 
capacity of districts and townships for risk analysis, risk communication, and 
community  preparedness;  (v)  improving  capacity  of  district  and  township 
outbreak  response,  including  provision  of  vehicles  and  equipment;  and  (vi) 
improving  screening  and  quarantine  capacity  at  border  entry  points  and 
quarantine centers. The project will provide expertise for system design, capacity 
building,  information  technolology  equipment,  vehicles,  and  equipment  for 
screening and outbreak control. 
 
(iii)  Output 3: Laboratory services and hospital infection prevention and control 
improved. This output will strengthen APSED focus areas 3, 5, 6, and 8 (para. 
10). Under this output, the project will support improving biosafety and quality of 
laboratory services, and expanding services for CDC. Project inputs will include 
(i) conducting staff training on internal quality improvement to provincial, district 
and/or  township  hospitals;  (ii)  preparing  standard  operating  procedures;  (iii) 
providing  basic  equipment,  supplies,  and  minor  repairs  for  laboratories;  (iv) 
setting up external quality assurance and audit systems for compliance with 
national biosafety and quality guidelines; and (v) setting up laboratory networks. 
The project will improve IPC at district hospitals through training in hygiene and 
case management, provision of basic equipment, and minor repairs of wards.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  The MOHs in CLMV will be the executing agencies in each country. The executing 
agency has overall responsibility for in-country project implementation and coordination among 
countries.  Each  executing  agency  has  a  senior  official  as  a  project  director  for  project 
management and liaison with ADB. The GMS Health Security Regional Steering Committee will 
guide project implementation, policy dialogue, building of regional capacity and cooperation for 
CDC. It will be chaired by the minister or vice-minister of the host country and will consist of 
representatives  from  the  MOHs,  ADB,  and  WHO.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the project administration manual.20

8 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
23.  Technical  challenges  at  the  regional  level  include  (i)  ensuring  leadership  for 
strengthening  regional  and  cross-border  cooperation,  (ii)  implementing  costly  and  complex 
strategies to improve health service access for MEVs in border areas, and (iii) implementing 
appropriate  strategies  for  quality  improvement  of  laboratory  services  and  improvement  of 
infection control in hospitals. The project provides for capacity building and support in these 
areas. WHO will provide technical support and training for disease control strategies, quality 
control of laboratories, and improvement of IPC in hospitals. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
24.  The economic rationale for investing in the project lies in the nature of health security 
being a regional public good. CDC interventions including public education, epidemiological 
surveillance,  cross-border  vector  control,  and  regional  cooperation  positively  impact  labor 
productivity and directly reduce the burden of disease for individuals and households. The 
economic internal rate of return on the project investment is estimated to be 21.8% over a 10-
year benefit stream for CLMV combined. The economic benefits accrue from (i) a narrowing of 
the health status and disease incidence gaps between target areas and the rest of country, (ii) 
aversion  or  mitigation  of  epidemic  outbreaks  as  a  percentage  of  national  gross  domestic 
product, and (iii) effective lab testing and subsequent treatment of particular communicable 
diseases (e.g., dengue). Recurrent costs are assumed not to decline in the 5 years following 
project implementation but represent less than 0.27% of projected annual government health 
expenditure in CLMV. Given this small percentage and the headroom for expanding government 
health  expenditure,  the  project  is  considered  financially  viable  and  sustainable  in  all  four 
countries. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
25.  Fiduciary risk in the health sector of the four countries has been assessed as high in 
Myanmar,  substantial  in  Cambodia,  and  moderate  in  the  Lao  PDR  and  Viet  Nam.  The 
procurement risk assessment is considered high in the Lao PDR and Myanmar, and moderate 
in Viet Nam and Cambodia. The MOHs in CLMV lack the necessary human resources for 
procurement and financial management. However the MOHs of Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and 
Viet Nam have gained substantial experience in implementing ADB-assisted projects over the 
years and have staff trained in ADB procedures. Myanmar MOH has limited experience in ADB 
standards for financial management and procurement, so the staff will receive training in ADB 
procedures. The CLMV governments have given assurances that capable government staff will 
be appointed in a timely manner. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
discussed with the government. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are in the project administration manual (footnote 20). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
26.   Neglected  communicable  diseases,  along  with  HIV/AIDS,  tuberculosis,  and  malaria 
contribute as a group to the top ten factors of burden of disease.21 The poor especially suffer 
                                                
21 World Health Organization. 2010. The Global Burden of Disease Study. Geneva.

9 
from communicable diseases that are easily treated or prevented, but have limited access to the 
health  care  infrastructure,  and  sanitation  facilities.  The  project  will  contribute  to  poverty 
reduction primarily by preventing the spread of communicable diseases and major epidemics, 
and improving access to diagnostics and treatment, thus reducing medical expenses, morbidity, 
mortality, and related household impact. 
 
27.   Multiple factors limit women’s access to and affordability of health services, including 
cultural  perceptions,  travel  distance,  potential  safety  risks,  and  financial  resources.  Health 
services do not sufficiently consider the specific needs of women. The current surveillance 
system does not include the reporting of sex-disaggregated data. The project is categorized as 
effective gender mainstreaming as it will directly improve women’s access to health services. To 
ensure the effectiveness of gender mainstreaming and gender-related outcomes in the project, 
MOHs in CLMV will implement the gender action plan.22 The gender mainstreaming actions 
include (i) strengthening national sex-disaggregated surveillance systems; (ii) conducting CDC 
outreach activities targeting women and girls with gender-sensitive materials; and (iii) ensuring 
participation of female health staff in training, and in regional workshops.. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
28.  The project is classified as category B for indigenous peoples. Ethnic minorities in the 
project areas will be positively affected as they will have better access to improved health 
services. An indigenous peoples development plan has been prepared for each country, and 
includes measures to ensure ethnic minority groups benefit from the project. The project is 
classified as category C for involuntary resettlement. There will be no construction of new health 
facilities or extension of existing health facilities, and no land acquisition is required. Screening 
during the selection of health facilities to be refurbished will rule out proposed sites, which 
require land acquisition and have resettlement impacts. The project is classified as category B 
for environment, as the project has components dealing with laboratory biohazards and hospital 
solid and liquid waste management. Mitigation measures are included in the environmental 
management plan to address minor environmental risks. An initial environmental examination 
and an environmental assessment and review framework have been prepared. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
29.  The risk for the project is assessed as medium in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet 
Nam, and high in Myanmar. Major risks include (i) insufficient administrative capacity for project-
related financial management and procurement; (ii) complexity of financial management linked 
to the large number of implementing agencies; and (iii) limited health human resources for 
laboratory improvements and IPC activities. Mitigation measures include (i) involving provinces, 
regions, and states in the preparation of annual operation plans; (ii) hiring consultants for initial 
technical  and  administrative  assistance  and  producing  financial  management  manuals;  (iii) 
training project staff; and (iv) conducting all procurement activities at the central government 
level. In addition, the MOH of Myanmar will be assisted with up-front financial management and 
procurement  consultants  and  training  by  ADB.  The  integrated  benefits  and  impacts  are 
expected to outweigh the risks of the project. Major risks and mitigating measures are described 
in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan. 23  
 
                                                
22 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
23 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
   
30.  The governments and the MOHs of Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam 
have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all applicable ADB 
policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, 
consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in  the  project  administration 
manual and loan documents. The governments and the executing agencies have agreed with 
ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan and grant agreements.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
31.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans and grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve  
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR15,012,000 to the Kingdom of 
Cambodia  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Health  Security  Project,  from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per 
annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 
years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions 
as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement 
presented to the Board; 
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR2,856,000 to the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic for the Greater Mekong Subregion Health Security Project, 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% 
per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
agreement presented to the Board; 
(iii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR8,616,000 to the Republic of the 
Union of Myanmar for the Greater Mekong Subregion Health Security Project, 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% 
per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
agreement presented to the Board; 
(iv)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR56,946,000  to  the  Socialist 
Republic of Viet Nam for the Greater Mekong Subregion Health Security Project, 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 2.0% 
per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  thereafter;  for  a  term  of  25  years, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  agreement 
presented to the Board; and 
(v)  the grant not exceeding $8,000,000 to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources, for the Greater Mekong Subregion Health 
Security Project, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
                                                                                                   Takehiko Nakao
